profileText: A Representative from New York; born in Salem, N.Y., July 31, 1799; attended the common schools, and was graduated from Washington Academy, Salem, N.Y., in 1818; studied law; was admitted to the bar in 1823 and commenced practice in Salem, N.Y., but shortly afterward moved to Whitehall, N.Y.; elected justice of the peace in 1828 and served for many years; member of the State assembly in 1840; supervisor of Whitehall in 1845, 1848, and 1849; elected as a Whig to the Thirty-second Congress (March 4, 1851-March 3, 1853); special surrogate of Washington County 1857-1859; elected president of the village; resumed the practice of law; died in Whitehall, Washington County, N.Y., on July 2, 1868; interment in Evergreen Cemetery, Salem, N.Y.

researchRecord.name: 1835-1863, 2 boxes.
researchRecord.description: The papers consist of letters, legal papers, surveys, and receipts. The bulk of the correspondence covers the period of his term (1851-1853), and reflects the feelings of his Whig constituents on the principal issues before Congress. Of particular interest are a number of letters regarding railroad construction in Washington County, New York. Also included are a number of papers dealing with John Boyd's property holdings. Among these papers are receipts for workmen's wages and leases. An unpublished guide is available in the repository.

researchRecord.name: In the Local History Collection, 1808-1982, 12 cubic feet.
researchRecord.description: Includes receipts, notes, and bills concerning John H. Boyd, 1826-1862.

researchRecord.name: 1828-1863, 1.5 cubic feet
researchRecord.description: The papers are on permanent loan from the New York State Historical Association, Cooperstown, New York. Includes business records belonging to John Boyd, consisting of letters, notes, mortgages, deeds, orders, bills, agreements, receipts, leases, and account books.
